chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text:
First, we have to find out the actual value of the firm which we denote with $AV$, where the earnings before interest and taxes $EI$ is $\$51,000$, tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$ and the cost of equity $CE$ is $9.6\%$

$$\begin{align*}
AV&=\frac{EI \times (1-TR)}{CE}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{51,000 \times (1-21\%)}{9.6\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{51,000 \times (1-0.21)}{0.096}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{51,000 \times 0.79}{0.096}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{40,290}{0.096}\\[12pt]
&=419,687.5
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the actual value of the firm is $\boxed{\$419,687.5}$

Second, we have to find out the current value of the firm according to the $M\&M$ proposition $I$ which we denote with $CVF$, where the actual value of the firm $AV$ is $\$419,687.5$, tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$ and the debt outstanding $DO$ is $\$126,000$

$$\begin{align*}
CVF&=AV+(TR \times DO)\\[7pt]
&=419,687.5+(21\% \times 126,000)\\[7pt]
&=419,687.5 + (0.21 \times 126,000)\\[7pt]
&=419,687.5 +26,460\\[7pt]
&=446,147.5
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the current value of the firm according to the $M\&M$ proposition $I$ is $\boxed{\$446,147.5}$

The firm's debt-to-equity ratio must be changed to boost the firm's worth, this must change theÂ overall capital structure since it can be observed that the firm's worth grew whenever the tax implications were applied to the unlevered firm and debt has been included.

 If certain costs were neglected, the corporation should raise its debt-to-equity ratios in order to improve the firm's worth.
